message:
Human psychology is immensely complex, nuanced, and often contradictory, with significant portions operating outside conscious awareness. AI, even advanced language models, operates on algorithms and data. While it can process language, it lacks true intuition, lived experience, and the capacity to grasp the intricate nature of human emotional life.

At PsiAN, we believe that therapies of depth, insight, and relationship aim to understand and resolve the underlying psychological conflicts and patterns that give rise to symptoms. The goal is not just symptom reduction but profound personal growth and healthier ways of relating to self and others.

Join PsiAN today if you share these values.

#HumanTherapy #DepthPsychology #MentalHealthMatters #PsiAN

Considering AI for mental health support? Be aware of the limitations, especially when it comes to accessing the unconscious mind.

AI can mimic empathy, but it cannot truly understand the complex, often hidden motivations and conflicts that drive our feelings. This can lead to superficial "solutions" and potentially dangerous responses during crises.

Without a human therapist to navigate these dynamics, vital insights and true relational healing are missed. And ethical concerns over data privacy remain significant.

Learn more about what leads to lasting therapeutic change at PsiAN.org

#AITherapy #MentalHealthRisks #HumanConnection #PsiAN

The Psychotherapy Action Network (PsiAN) is committed to standing against AI-based therapy that lacks genuine human connection and fighting back against corporate agendas that seek to commercialize mental healthcare.

Research highlights how the combination of private equity and AI creates a concerning pairing for patient privacy and quality of care. Therapy isn't a commodity.

PsiAN advocates for quality mental health treatment, including therapies of depth, insight, and relationship. Join this important work and volunteer with PsiAN today.

#PsiAN #HumanTherapy #MentalHealthAction #DepthTherapy

Mental health apps: Convenient, but are they enough?

Technology can assist, but apps cannot fully replace the nuanced connection of human-to-human therapy. While they may be useful tools for some purposes, apps are not replacements for therapists.

Many mental health apps also operate outside of HIPAA regulations, giving them more leeway in handling user data. Reports indicate that numerous apps collect and share sensitive information—including mental health symptoms, personal details, and usage patterns—with data brokers and advertisers.

The drive for profit can overshadow user privacy and ethical considerations. Let's use tech wisely.

#mentalhealth #therapy #tech #mentalhealthawareness #digitalhealth #PsiAN

Healing isn't a quick fix. It's a journey.

Long-term, depth-based therapy allows for deep exploration, lasting change, and building a truly resilient self. True growth comes from understanding the roots of our patterns, building healthier connections, and embracing our authentic selves.

PsiAN believes the work extends beyond symptom management. Depth-oriented psychotherapy fosters lasting change by addressing core relational patterns:

• Understanding the impact of past experiences
• Building secure attachment
• Developing emotional regulation
• Cultivating self-awareness

Research consistently shows that the quality of the therapeutic relationship is one of the strongest predictors of successful outcomes.

Support PsiAN and our mission by joining our organization—it's FREE.

#therapy #mentalhealth #healing #relationaltherapy #depthpsychology #therapyworks #PsiAN

"Rome wasn't built in a day." "Old habits die hard." "All in good time."

The wisdom of these sayings is obvious—so why wouldn't they apply to therapy as well?

It's understandable to want a quick fix to psychological problems. No one wants to prolong their distress. But quick fixes work for the moment, not the long haul.

At PsiAN, we advocate for depth psychology: treatment that examines early experiences and how they impact your current behavior, thoughts, feelings, and relationships. Understanding how persistent patterns came to be—and working through how they affect your life—is the most effective path to lasting change.

They say Rome wasn't built in a day. You weren't built in a day either. It takes time to achieve mental wellness, but it's time well spent.

Learn more at PsiAN.org

#depthpsychology #therapy #mentalhealth #healing #PsiAN

Working with a therapist over an extended period can lead to lasting, positive changes for many people.

While short-term therapy has benefits, research tells a compelling story:

One study found that those in long-term therapy experienced "larger and more sustained benefits" with improved self-concept and personality functioning.

Another study found that compared to short-term therapy, longer-term treatment was associated with higher remission rates, greater work ability improvements, and significantly better symptom reduction.

If you're a therapist, consider joining the Psychotherapy Action Network. By getting involved, you can help support our mission to promote increased access to therapies that make a real-world difference.

#therapy #research #mentalhealth #longterm #PsiAN

The term "gold standard" in therapy is often misleading—and it primarily benefits insurance companies at the expense of patients.

Recent research titled "More treatment but no less depression: The treatment-prevalence paradox" describes a puzzling finding: increased availability of short-term therapies hasn't reduced depression rates.

This isn't surprising to depth therapists who understand that relational problems developed over years or decades require more than a few weeks to meaningfully address.

The researchers themselves acknowledge that benefits from short-term treatments are often modest, rarely sustained, and don't translate well to real-world settings.

Therapies of depth, insight, and relationship address deeper emotional patterns, fostering lasting transformation. Research shows patients in these therapies continue improving for years after treatment ends.

Choosing depth-oriented therapy means investing in meaningful, enduring emotional wellbeing—not just temporary relief.

#TherapyThatSticks #depthpsychology #mentalhealth #PsiAN

Thinking about using a therapy app? Here's what you should know before taking that step:

1. Apps like BetterHelp and TalkSpace are tech companies first, mental health practices second. Their priority is platform expansion; mental health is the product.

2. "24/7 therapist access" sounds appealing, but research shows it's not therapeutic. Consistency—same person, same time, same place—creates the safety essential for real therapeutic work.

3. Effective psychotherapy relies on two things: a consistent relationship with and trust in your therapist. That's difficult with anonymous, potentially changing "therapists."

4. These platforms have the potential to share your data with third parties to serve their growth. Your struggles may become their business asset.

5. App-based therapy is limited in what it can address. They're not equipped for serious mental health crises, and sometimes operate contrary to best practices.

6. Research supports the efficacy of long-term, relationship-based psychotherapy. Most people seeking therapy want a lasting solution with an in-person therapist.

If you're ready to start therapy with a safe, consistent, effective approach, visit PsiAN.org for resources.

#therapy #mentalhealth #therapyapps #PsiAN

In addition to destigmatizing psychotherapy, PsiAN has taken on the challenge of shedding light on injustices perpetrated by insurance companies in mental health treatment.

Whether it's clawing back payments, demanding confidential patient notes, or creating complex administrative systems, these companies are driving psychologists out of insurance networks—which ultimately reduces patient access to care.

This is unacceptable, and something PsiAN is actively fighting. But we need your help.

Join, donate, or volunteer with PsiAN and help us push back against the practices insurance companies use to deny or limit life-saving mental health treatment.

#mentalhealth #insurance #therapy #advocacy #PsiAN

Before turning to ChatGPT or other AI platforms for mental health support, it's worth understanding their limitations.

These tools lack the judgment, human connection, and nuanced thinking that effective psychotherapy requires. A recent New York Times investigation found that AI chatbot responses can sometimes lead users toward harmful conclusions rather than helpful ones.

At PsiAN, we're committed to helping you make informed decisions about your mental health care. Quality therapy is built on depth, insight, and genuine human relationship.

Learn more at www.PsiAN.org

#mentalhealth #AI #therapy #PsiAN

That friendly, comforting face offering therapy advice? It may be a chatbot—not a licensed professional.

A recent 404 Media investigation found AI-powered "therapists" on Instagram claiming credentials that don't exist, offering mental health guidance without any clinical oversight.

Authentic therapy requires a real human relationship: someone who can truly understand your unique experience and provide consistent, ethical care.

At PsiAN, we advocate for therapy built on depth, insight, and genuine connection.

Learn more at www.PsiAN.org

#mentalhealth #AI #therapy #PsiAN

Some AI chatbots are presenting themselves as licensed therapists—complete with fabricated credentials and license numbers that don't check out.

They promise better outcomes, 24/7 availability, and improved mental health. But they cannot replace what research consistently shows matters most: a trusted, consistent relationship with a real human therapist.

PsiAN is committed to educating the public about these emerging risks. Effective therapy requires depth, insight, and authentic human connection.

Visit www.PsiAN.org to learn more.

#mentalhealth #AI #therapy #PsiAN

We're spotlighting Dr. Felecia Powell-Williams—a powerhouse in psychotherapy and PsiAN Board Member.

As a distinguished psychoanalyst, Dr. Powell-Williams champions depth, insight, and the profound importance of the therapeutic relationship in healing. She recognized early in her career the "limitations of short-term treatment" and the need for "deeper, more sustained therapeutic relationships."

Her work with children and families in the foster care system, and her experience as the only psychoanalyst of color in Texas, underscores her dedication to culturally informed, human-centered care.

To learn more about Dr. Powell-Williams' career and work with PsiAN, check out this interview with Bevin Campbell, PsyD.

Thank you for all you bring to our mission, Dr. Powell-Williams.

#MemberSpotlight #DepthTherapy #PsychoanalyticPsychology #TherapeuticRelationship #PsiAN #MentalHealthEquity

We're spotlighting the vital work of Dr. Usha Tummala-Narra, PsiAN Board Member and Professor at Boston College.

A leading voice in clinical psychology, Dr. Tummala-Narra brilliantly integrates psychoanalytic theory with multicultural psychology. Her research illuminates how race, immigration, and trauma profoundly shape mental well-being and identity.

Dr. Tummala-Narra's advocacy for culturally informed psychoanalytic psychotherapy aligns with PsiAN's mission for human-centered therapies that focus on depth, insight, and relationships.

As she states: "It is my hope that psychoanalysis moves in the direction of conceptualizing the specifics of diversity and diverse contexts as essential components that shape the psyche."

#MemberSpotlight #PsiAN #PsychoanalyticPsychology #MulticulturalMentalHealth #MentalHealthMatters

At PsiAN, we believe the most effective therapies are those that emphasize insight, depth, and the therapeutic relationship.

Insight leads to breaking old patterns and creating new, more adaptive ones.

Depth addresses the root causes of mental distress, not just symptoms.

Relationship with your therapist—in a trusting, consistent, compassionate, and confidential environment—supports both insight and depth work.

Visit PsiAN.org to learn more about our mission and how to find quality care.

#mentalhealth #therapy #insight #depth #PsiAN

What does "mental health" really mean?

In our tech-heavy, information-saturated culture, the term gets assigned misleading labels. We're bombarded with messages insisting therapy can and should be quick, requiring minimal commitment, and available as conveniently as food delivery apps.

At PsiAN, we're committed to countering myths that prevent people from getting the help they need in a safe and reliable environment. And we have research to support what actually works.

Effective therapy isn't fast food. It's a relationship that unfolds over time. Visit www.PsiAN.org for more.

#mentalhealth #therapy #PsiAN

AI chatbots are not therapists or crisis services. For some vulnerable individuals, they can be more harmful than helpful.

Several people have died by suicide after using AI chatbots. People experiencing psychosis, eating disorders, and substance use disorders are at higher risk—and have had their conditions worsened by AI interactions.

If you're in crisis, please reach out to supports that can help, such as the 988 crisis hotline.

If you're experiencing mental health concerns, consultation with a licensed professional is your best path to appropriate support.

www.psian.org

#mentalhealth #crisis #AI #988 #PsiAN

Research consistently shows that therapies of depth, insight, and relationship are evidence-based treatments highly effective in both short and long term.

Decades of research also demonstrate that effective therapy takes time. Meaningful change typically begins around the six-month mark and only increases from there.

It's more important than ever to look past ads and corporate messaging. For many companies, shorter treatment means lower costs—regardless of patient outcomes.

PsiAN advocates for treatments that work: approaches that address complexity, recognize that many problems develop over generations, and provide lasting benefit.

#therapy #research #mentalhealth #PsiAN

In "The Therapy World Has Changed: Where Are We Now?", Santiago Delboy and PsiAN co-founder Linda L. Michaels compiled years of research on public attitudes toward mental health and psychotherapy.

Their key finding: "The general public still resonates with and values what therapies of depth, insight, and relationship can offer."

PsiAN is working to highlight research, advocacy efforts, and policies that promote sustained, long-lasting therapeutic change. Join us in this work.

#therapy #research #mentalhealth #PsiAN

Many insurance companies don't seem pleased that more people are seeking out psychotherapy.

The reach of insurers into the therapy room has been expanding for years: narrowly defining "evidence-based therapy," rationing care through "value-based care" models, leaving therapists between a rock and a hard place.

At PsiAN, we believe that everyone who desires confidential, quality, individualized, ethical, and compassionate therapy deserves access. We stand with therapists making difficult decisions to care for their communities with integrity.

Mental health is political. Policy directly impacts both people with mental health concerns and those whose job it is to support them.

#mentalhealth #insurance #therapy #advocacy #PsiAN

Therapies of depth, insight, and relationship start with a simple, human premise: our most troubling beliefs once protected us. They were solutions to real conditions, often in family or developmental contexts.

Instead of debating those beliefs in the present, we ask: "When did they begin? With whom? What did they help you survive?" This lens invites compassion and curiosity rather than shame.

In a steady therapeutic relationship, these answers are felt and experienced—something far more powerful than cognitive understanding alone. Old expectations are reworked in real time, offering new experiences of safety, repair, and choice.

#depthpsychology #therapy #mentalhealth #insight #PsiAN

Skill-building and quick fixes can be helpful. But therapy of depth, insight, and relationship asks a different question: Why do the same patterns keep returning? We look for the story behind the symptom.

Patterns are relational. They formed with important others, often in our families, and they inevitably appear in our other relationships too. Noticing them together—in the here-and-now—turns therapy into a living laboratory.

The changes that happen in a therapeutic relationship get internalized as direct counterweights to earlier relational harm. Patients live the experience that things can be different and better.

#therapy #depthpsychology #relational #mentalhealth #PsiAN

What does therapy of depth, insight, and relationship look like in practice?

We slow down. We track and experience emotion as deeply as possible. We listen for meanings held in the body and in memory—especially during early relationships.

We make room for the disavowed. We all show parts of ourselves and hide others. Depth therapy attempts to reclaim these losses.

We find reasons for symptoms and patterns—usually dating back years or decades. This understanding helps release their grip.

We pay close attention to the relationship unfolding in therapy. An attuned therapist helps us see these dynamics unfold and works toward healthier ways of relating.

#depthpsychology #therapy #healing #mentalhealth #PsiAN

The Hidden Toll of "Taking Insurance" in Therapy

It sounds simple: pay for therapy with your insurance. But for many dedicated therapists, working with insurance companies is an administrative burden that takes time away from patient care.

The hassle: Hours spent fighting for authorization, mountains of claim forms, and reimbursement rates that barely cover practice costs.

The control: Invasive demands for private patient information and "medical necessity" requirements that dictate how and how long you can receive care.

This is why many therapists choose to be self-pay only. It's about protecting their energy to focus entirely on you and provide ethical care free from corporate interference.

#SelfPayTherapy #TherapyTruth #MentalHealthAdvocate #PsiAN

When a therapist chooses to stop accepting insurance, it's rarely a casual decision. It's often an act of self-preservation and a commitment to better client care.

Undervalued work: Reimbursement rates often aren't sustainable, forcing therapists to see more patients than is clinically ideal.

Invasive control: Insurance companies demand detailed private data and can interfere with treatment decisions.

The fight: Days spent on hold, appealing rejected claims, battling systems that prioritize profit over patient wellbeing.

Going self-pay means a therapist can invest time in training, consultation, and focused care—rather than fighting bureaucratic systems.

#TherapistLife #SelfPayOnly #MentalHealthMatters #PsiAN

Insurance in mental health: the good, the bad, and the ugly.

The good: Coverage can increase access to care for people who otherwise couldn't afford it.

The bad: Low reimbursement rates, prior authorization requirements, ghost networks, and frequent claim denials.

The ugly: Insurers effectively dictate patient care—shorter sessions, capped frequency, pressure to assign diagnoses for billing rather than clinical accuracy.

PsiAN wants to make these profit-driven problems more visible. Use our Insurance Issue Tracker to log denials, delays, clawbacks, and credentialing issues.

#insurance #mentalhealth #therapy #advocacy #PsiAN

Self-pay therapy is a difficult decision for both clinicians and patients.

For clinicians, it's weighing reach versus the ability to practice responsibly: protect privacy, set session length based on need, maintain continuity, and prevent treatment from being shaped by insurer rules.

If you're a patient, you may still be able to make self-pay work. Check your out-of-network benefits, deductibles, and HSA/FSA options. Ask therapists about sliding scale fees and superbills.

Plan ahead with your therapist to estimate frequency and duration, so you can budget accurately.

#therapy #selfpay #mentalhealth #PsiAN

New PsiAN research is here.

We surveyed 667 mental health professionals about their views on practice management companies—services that support therapists with insurance credentialing, billing, and administration.

Key topics of concern: privacy, transparency of investors, reimbursement rates and pay, ethics, and overall satisfaction with services offered.

We hope this research serves as a starting point for improvements that make this field sustainable for therapists and improve access to quality mental healthcare for everyone who needs it.

Read the summary and full analysis at psian.org/practice-management-companies

#research #therapy #mentalhealth #PsiAN

Amplify the Silence: The Power of Advocacy in Mental Health

Mental health access isn't just a clinical issue—it's a societal one.

As therapists and allies, advocacy extends our work beyond the therapy room. It means actively working to ensure everyone can access quality care, regardless of systemic barriers.

Addressing systemic barriers: When policies restrict funding or limit coverage, they compound individual suffering. Advocacy addresses the structural side of mental health.

Ensuring access and equity: We must speak up against policies that create barriers.

Advocacy isn't partisan—it's caring for collective wellbeing. Join PsiAN today.

#MentalHealthAdvocacy #Psychotherapy #MentalHealthAccess #PsiAN
